overview_of_class: This course offers an introduction to the study of music as a culturally contingent and historically situated phenomenon. We will explore a range of musical practices?both past and present?as they relate to broader webs of culture and society. Thus, rather than bracket off "world music" traditions from Western ones, this class seeks to understand music as integral to human experience, as a way of being in the world and making sense of our place in it. The course objectives are threefold. First, we will seek to challenge preconceptions of what music is, has been, and might be, with the aim of exploring alternative ways of thinking about music. Next, we will work to develop listening skills and to learn a critical vocabulary with which to describe our musical experiences. Finally, we will reflect on our own experiences with music and aim to situate them within their cultural, social, and historical contexts. Class meetings will consist of guided discussions of assigned readings and listening examples, and assignments will include topical quizzes, weekly journals, short essays, and exams.

overview_of_class: In this introductory music course, students will explore historical and cultural aspects of music in order to critically listen to and engage with music they might encounter in Western society today. Students will begin by developing skills to recognize, describe, and reflect on elements of diverse types of music. We will then approach the study of music based on various themes: religion, theater, dance, politics, technology, etc. Within these themes, music will be considered in relation to race, class, gender, and other aspects of culture and society. Students will be evaluated based on participation and attendance, weekly journal entries, short written assignments, and a final project/exam.
